title: Regional Recycling and Delivery Network

title: Laptop Rental and Return Logistics for Educational Institutions
content: A tech company rents laptops to schools and universities, requiring deliveries (linehaul) to campuses followed by pickups of returned devices (backhaul). The company uses multiple regional depots to serve educational hubs, ensuring trucks first distribute equipment before retrieving devices for maintenance or redistribution. Capacity limits on trucks must account for both outbound rentals and inbound returns, with routes concluding at regional tech centers for device sanitization and repairs.

title: Car Sharing Station Deployment and Retrieval Network
content: A car-sharing service deploys vehicles to urban stations (linehaul) while collecting returned cars for maintenance or redistribution (backhaul). Multiple depots act as central hubs for regional operations, with vehicles prioritizing station restocking before picking up idle or damaged cars. Each truck must adhere to capacity limits, ensuring they can carry both new deployments and retrieved vehicles. Routes end at maintenance facilities, eliminating the need to return to origin depots after completing all tasks.

title: Billboard Installation and Removal Logistics
content: A billboard advertising firm must deliver new promotional materials to outdoor display locations (linehaul customers) while simultaneously collecting outdated ads from existing sites (backhaul customers). Each billboard site has specific size requirements for new installations and varying quantities of obsolete material to be retrieved. Vehicles depart from multiple regional depots (MD) and must first complete all deliveries before initiating pickups to comply with backhaul constraints. Routes are designed to end at the final customer location (O), ensuring that vehicle capacities (C) are not exceeded while minimizing total travel distance.

title: Sports Tournament Equipment Distribution and Retrieval
content: A multinational sports federation organizes simultaneous regional competitions requiring the delivery of standardized athletic equipment (linehaul) to venues across multiple cities. After events conclude, damaged or excess gear must be collected (backhaul) for redistribution or repair. Using vehicles from decentralized depots (MD), logistics teams must first deploy equipment to all assigned venues before executing reverse logistics pickups. Routes terminate at the final stop (O), with strict adherence to vehicle weight limits (C) to avoid overloading during mixed equipment/materials transport.

title: Trade Show Booth Assembly and Dismantling Logistics
content: A convention services provider arranges modular booth systems for concurrent trade shows in different urban centers. Teams must first deliver prefabricated display components (linehaul) to exhibition halls, then dismantle and collect reusable parts (backhaul) post-event. With depots (MD) strategically located near major cities, vehicles must prioritize assembly deliveries before initiating disassembly pickups. Routes conclude at the last serviced location (O), balancing payload capacities (C) between heavy construction materials and lightweight recyclable components.

title: Temporary Medical Clinic Supply and Waste Retrieval
content: A global health NGO operates mobile clinics in disaster-prone regions, requiring rapid deployment of medical kits (linehaul) to field locations followed by hazardous waste collection (backhaul). Vehicles stationed at multiple regional hubs (MD) must first distribute sterile supplies, then retrieve biohazard materials for safe disposal. Open routes (O) end at the final clinic site, ensuring that vehicle capacities (C) accommodate both outbound sterile cargo and return waste streams without cross-contamination risks.

title: Agricultural Machinery Deployment and废旧 Parts Recycling
content: An agribusiness conglomerate modernizes farming operations by delivering new tractors and harvesters (linehaul) to partner farms while simultaneously collecting obsolete machinery (backhaul) for recycling. Depots (MD) in agricultural belts coordinate routes to first service equipment needs, then retrieve outdated parts. Vehicles (C) must handle mixed cargo: heavy machinery on outbound legs and compacted metal scrap on return segments. Routes finalize at the last farm visited (O), optimizing fuel use and minimizing operational downtime.

title: Tech Device Rollout and Recycling Network
content: A multinational tech corporation operates multiple regional warehouses `<loc_depot>` to deploy new smartphones and laptops to retail stores `<loc_customer>`. Simultaneously, the same vehicles must collect outdated devices from recycling centers `<loc_customer>` for proper e-waste disposal. Each vehicle has a `<capacity>` kg limit, requiring deliveries (linehaul) to retailers to precede pickups (backhaul) from recycling hubs. Routes originate from depots but terminate at the final customer stop, avoiding unnecessary return trips. The challenge is to optimize multi-depot assignments while ensuring no vehicle overloads during combined outbound/inbound operations.

title: Temporary Medical Clinic Equipment Logistics
content: During a pandemic surge, medical NGOs set up emergency clinics in rural areas `<loc_customer>` using equipment shipped from `<loc_depot>` regional hubs. Vehicles first deliver critical supplies (ventilators, PPE, etc.) to clinics (linehaul), then collect used or surplus gear (backhaul) from deactivating sites. Each route must complete deliveries before pickups, with vehicle capacities `<capacity>` restricting the total weight of outbound/inbound cargo. Routes end at the last clinic, reducing logistical overhead. The goal is to balance depot workloads and minimize cross-country travel costs.

title: Offshore Supply and Waste Management Network
content: Offshore oil platforms `<loc_customer>` rely on supply ships departing from coastal depots `<loc_depot>` to deliver fuel, food, and machinery (linehaul). The same vessels then collect hazardous waste and empty containers (backhaul) from platforms en route back to shore. Each ship has a `<capacity>` ton limit, mandating that all deliveries occur before waste pickups. Routes conclude at the final waste collection point, avoiding depot returns. The challenge is to coordinate multi-depot deployments while adhering to strict weight limits for both outbound and inbound cargo.

title: Sports League Gear Distribution and Collection
content: A professional sports league uses regional logistics hubs `<loc_depot>` to distribute equipment (balls, uniforms, etc.) to stadiums `<loc_customer>` hosting matches (linehaul). After events, vehicles collect unused gear and damaged equipment (backhaul) from other venues. Each truck’s `<capacity>` restricts how much gear can be transported in both directions. Routes must first visit all delivery stops before proceeding to pickups, ending at the final collection point. The objective is to minimize total travel distance while ensuring efficient depot-to-venue resource allocation.

title: Rental Car Deployment and Retrieval Network
content: A car rental company with multiple city depots `<loc_depot>` sends vehicles to pickup locations `<loc_customer>` (linehaul) for customer reservations. After rentals, empty cars are retrieved from drop-off zones `<loc_customer>` (backhaul) and redistributed. Each transport truck can carry `<capacity>` vehicles, requiring deliveries to customers to precede car pickups. Routes terminate at the last drop-off or pickup point, eliminating return trips to base. The problem involves optimizing depot assignments and vehicle routing to balance load and reduce idle mileage.

title: Automated Teller Machine (ATM) Cash Logistics Network
content: A banking consortium operates from multiple regional depots (`<loc_depot>`) to service ATMs across urban areas. Each vehicle delivers fresh cash reserves (linehaul) to ATMs (`<loc_customer>`) while simultaneously collecting worn banknotes (backhaul). Vehicles must first complete all deliveries before initiating pickups to avoid overloading. Routes originate from depots but terminate at the final customer location, with trucks never returning to origin. The cash capacity (`<capacity>`) of each vehicle must not be exceeded during combined delivery and collection operations.

title: Home Appliance Repair and Recycling Service
content: A repair service company uses depots in different cities (`<loc_depot>`) to dispatch technicians carrying spare parts (linehaul) to customers’ homes (`<loc_customer>`). After fixing appliances, technicians collect废旧 components (backhaul) for recycling. Each vehicle must prioritize part deliveries before pickups to prevent capacity overflow (`<capacity>`). Routes end at the last serviced address, with technicians concluding their shift there rather than returning to depots.

title: Mobile Library Book Exchange and Collection System
content: A public library network operates from multiple branches (`<loc_depot>`) to deploy bookmobiles (`<capacity>`) to underserved neighborhoods (`<loc_customer>`). These vehicles first deliver new book collections (linehaul) to temporary stops and later gather returned books (backhaul) from the same locations. Routes are designed to start at branches but conclude at the final drop-off point, ensuring books are neither overstocked nor underloaded during transit.

title: Construction Material Delivery and Scrap Removal Network
content: A construction firm manages material distribution from several regional warehouses (`<loc_depot>`) to active building sites (`<loc_customer>`). Vehicles transport raw materials (linehaul) like lumber or cement to sites while also hauling scrap metal or debris (backhaul) for recycling. All deliveries must precede pickups to maintain payload balance (`<capacity>`). Routes originate at warehouses but end at the last site, avoiding return trips to depots.

title: Electric Vehicle Battery Swap Station Network
content: A green energy startup operates battery swap stations from decentralized depots (`<loc_depot>`). Vehicles deliver fully charged batteries (linehaul) to EV drivers at service points (`<loc_customer>`) and collect depleted batteries (backhaul) for recharging. Each truck must first complete all swaps before retrieving empty batteries to avoid overcapacity (`<capacity>`). Routes begin at depots but terminate at the final swap location, optimizing energy logistics without redundant return journeys.

title: Military Field Supply Delivery and废旧 Equipment Retrieval Network
content: A defense logistics operation uses multiple regional depots to supply remote military bases with critical linehaul items like ammunition, medical kits, and fuel. After completing deliveries, vehicles collect废旧 equipment (e.g., empty shell casings, damaged gear) for recycling or disposal. Each vehicle must not exceed its `<capacity>` ton limit, ensuring linehaul deliveries precede backhaul pickups. Routes terminate at the final废旧 collection point to avoid return trips, optimizing fuel efficiency and operational readiness.

title: Industrial Refrigeration Unit Delivery and废旧 Compressor Retrieval
content: A refrigeration company operates from multiple regional depots to deliver new industrial cooling units to manufacturing plants. After installation (linehaul), technicians retrieve废旧 compressors from outdated systems (backhaul). Vehicles must prioritize deliveries first to prevent capacity overloads, with routes ending at the final废旧 pickup location. This minimizes travel costs while supporting sustainable recycling practices.

title: Remote Research Station Supply and Waste Retrieval
content: Scientific research stations in remote regions rely on `<loc_depot>` depots to receive perishable supplies (food, lab equipment) via linehaul deliveries. Researchers return废旧 materials and waste (backhaul) for disposal. Vehicles from multiple depots must first deliver `<demand_linehaul>` supplies without exceeding `<capacity>` kg, then collect `<demand_backhaul>` waste. Routes conclude at the final waste collection point to reduce travel time and environmental impact.

title: Maritime Fuel Delivery and废旧 Filter Collection
content: A maritime logistics firm services fishing fleets by delivering fuel from coastal `<loc_depot>` hubs to vessels at sea (linehaul). After refueling, crews collect废旧 engine filters (backhaul) for recycling. Each vehicle must manage `<capacity>` liters of fuel and `<demand_backhaul>` kg of废旧 filters, ensuring deliveries precede pickups. Routes end at the last filter pickup site, cutting unnecessary return voyages.

title: Festival Equipment Deployment and Post-Event Waste Collection
content: A festival logistics provider deploys `<loc_depot>`-based teams to deliver stages, lighting, and sound systems (linehaul) to event sites. After the event, they collect post-show waste like decorations and packaging (backhaul). Vehicles from multiple depots must first transport `<demand_linehaul>` equipment without exceeding `<capacity>` ton limits, then gather `<demand_backhaul>` waste. Routes terminate at the final waste collection point to streamline operations and reduce costs.

title: International Courier Package Delivery and Return Logistics Network
content: A global courier company operates multiple regional hubs (`<loc_depot>`) to manage cross-border deliveries and customer returns. Vehicles departing from these hubs must first deliver international packages to specified addresses (`<loc_customer>`) with varying `<demand_linehaul>` weights. After completing all deliveries, they collect returned items (backhaul `<demand_backhaul>`) for reverse shipping. Each truck has a `<capacity>` limit, requiring careful load balancing to avoid overpacking. Routes are open-ended, ending at the final stop to minimize return trips. The challenge is to optimize depot assignments and route sequences while adhering to strict delivery-before-pickup rules.

title: Offshore Oil Rig Supplies and废旧 Equipment Retrieval Network
content: Oil companies use coastal depots (`<loc_depot>`) to supply remote offshore drilling platforms (`<loc_customer>`) with critical equipment and fuel (`<demand_linehaul>`). After delivering these items, vehicles must retrieve outdated or decommissioned machinery (`<demand_backhaul>`) from the same rigs. Each vessel has a `<capacity>` limit for both outbound and return cargo. Routes are planned as open tours, concluding at the last rig or a designated recycling facility. The goal is to coordinate multi-depot operations efficiently while ensuring linehaul deliveries precede backhaul pickups to prevent capacity overloads.

title: Aerospace Component Delivery and Used Rocket Part Collection
content: A space agency operates distribution centers (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver precision-engineered components (`<demand_linehaul>`) to satellite launch sites (`<loc_customer>`). Post-launch, these same routes are used to recover spent rocket stages or reusable equipment (`<demand_backhaul>`) for refurbishment. Vehicles must adhere to `<capacity>` limits, prioritizing component deliveries before backhauling returned hardware. Open routes end at remote launch pads or recovery zones, avoiding depot returns to streamline operations. The solution must balance multi-depot workflows while respecting the sequential delivery-pickup constraint.

title: Disaster Relief Supplies Distribution and Hazardous Waste Collection
content: In post-disaster scenarios, aid organizations deploy from `<loc_depot>` hubs to deliver emergency supplies (`<demand_linehaul>`) like water, tents, and medical kits to affected zones (`<loc_customer>`). After distribution, teams collect hazardous waste (e.g., contaminated materials, debris) as backhaul cargo (`<demand_backhaul>`). Vehicles are constrained by `<capacity>` to prevent overloading. Routes are open-ended, terminating at temporary waste-processing sites. The challenge involves coordinating multi-depot operations across disaster zones, ensuring linehaul deliveries occur before waste collection to safeguard crew safety and logistical efficiency.

title: Postal Service Mail Delivery and Package Collection Network
content: A national postal service uses regional sorting centers (`<loc_depot>`) to distribute mail (`<demand_linehaul>`) to residential and commercial addresses (`<loc_customer>`). Simultaneously, postal trucks collect parcels for outbound shipping (`<demand_backhaul>`) from the same locations. Each truck’s `<capacity>` must accommodate both outgoing mail and incoming packages without exceeding limits. Routes operate as open tours, concluding at the final stop to eliminate return journeys. The objective is to optimize multi-depot assignments and route sequences, ensuring all deliveries precede pickups to maintain postal service reliability and minimize operational costs.

title: Regional Medical Supplies and Waste Collection Network
content: A healthcare logistics provider operates multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver medical supplies (e.g., vaccines, PPE) to hospitals and clinics (`<loc_customer>`). After completing deliveries (linehaul), trucks collect biomedical waste and expired medications (backhaul) from the same locations. Each vehicle must prioritize deliveries before pickups to avoid contamination, with a maximum capacity (`<capacity>`) for combined loads. Routes are designed to end at the final customer stop (O), optimizing fuel use while ensuring all healthcare facilities receive essential supplies and hazardous materials are safely retrieved.

title: Film Production Equipment Rental and Post-Shoot Retrieval Network
content: A film equipment rental company deploys trucks from regional depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver cameras, lighting rigs, and sound gear (linehaul) to film locations (`<loc_customer>`). Post-production, trucks return to collect rented equipment (backhaul), ensuring pickups occur only after all deliveries are complete. Capacity constraints (`<capacity>`) limit the mix of outbound gear and inbound returns. Open routes let drivers finish at the last pickup site, minimizing redundant travel and maximizing operational efficiency for time-sensitive film schedules.

title: Tire Retailer’s New Tire Delivery and Used Tire Recycling Network
content: A chain of tire retailers uses multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) to supply new tires (linehaul) to automotive shops and customers (`<loc_customer>`). On the same routes, trucks collect used tires (backhaul) for recycling, ensuring pickups follow deliveries to prevent cross-contamination. Each vehicle must stay within its capacity (`<capacity>`) for both outbound and return loads. Open routes conclude at the final drop-off/retrieval point, reducing fuel costs while supporting sustainable waste management practices.

title: Agricultural Honeybee Hive Deployment and Pollination Retrieval Network
content: Beekeepers operate multiple apiary depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver honeybee hives (linehaul) to farms for seasonal pollination (`<loc_customer>`). After crops are pollinated, trucks retrieve the hives (backhaul), ensuring pickups never precede deliveries to avoid disturbing active colonies. Capacity (`<capacity>`) limits depend on hive size and vehicle space. Open routes end at the last hive collection site, streamlining logistics for perishable agricultural timelines.

title: Pop-Up Event Stage Setup and Post-Festival Dismantling Logistics
content: An events company manages multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) to transport temporary stages, tents, and equipment (linehaul) to festival venues (`<loc_customer>`). After events conclude, trucks dismantle and collect materials (backhaul), adhering to capacity (`<capacity>`) limits for both delivery and return loads. Open routes allow crews to finish at the final dismantling location, eliminating empty return trips and enabling rapid redeployment for subsequent events.

title: Temporary Event Stage Setup and Equipment Retrieval
content: A company specializing in music festivals uses multiple depots (<loc_depot>) to dispatch trucks (capacity `<capacity>`) to deploy modular stage structures, lighting rigs, and audio equipment to event sites (<loc_customer>). Each site requires a specific amount of equipment (`<demand_linehaul>`), while post-event, the same trucks must collect dismantled materials (`<demand_backhaul>`). All deliveries must precede pickups to avoid overloaded vehicles during retrieval. Routes are open-ended, ending at the final collection point to minimize fuel use and operational costs.

title: Modular Construction Unit Delivery and Scrap Retrieval
content: A construction firm operates from regional depots (<loc_depot>) to deliver pre-fabricated wall panels and HVAC systems (`<demand_linehaul>`) to building sites (<loc_customer>). After installation, trucks return to the same routes to collect scrap metal and debris (`<demand_backhaul>`) from demolition zones. Vehicles must first complete deliveries to ensure sufficient capacity for bulky waste pickup. Open routes terminate at the last scrap collection site, optimizing fleet efficiency across multiple depots.

title: Disaster Response Shelter Deployment and Hazardous Waste Collection
content: Following a flood, aid organizations use multi-depot (<loc_depot>) logistics to deliver emergency shelters, medical kits (`<demand_linehaul>`), and water purifiers to disaster zones (<loc_customer>). Post-relief, trucks revisit affected areas to collect contaminated waste (`<demand_backhaul>`) for disposal. Backhauls are sequenced after deliveries to prevent capacity overflow, with routes ending at waste consolidation hubs to avoid depot return costs.

title: Agricultural Drone Delivery and Maintenance Retrieval
content: A precision farming service operates from rural depots (<loc_depot>) to deploy crop-monitoring drones (`<demand_linehaul>`) to farms (<loc_customer>). After data collection, drones are retrieved for battery swaps and maintenance (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each truck must first deliver all drones before collecting used units, ensuring payload limits are respected. Open routes end at the final farm to reduce empty vehicle mileage.

title: Temporary Medical Testing Site Setup and Dismantling
content: A healthcare logistics provider uses multiple depots (<loc_depot>) to deliver mobile testing units, PPE, and lab equipment (`<demand_linehaul>`) to high-need areas (<loc_customer>). Once testing concludes, trucks return to dismantle and collect equipment (`<demand_backhaul>`), adhering to strict capacity limits for hazardous material transport. Routes are designed as one-way paths, ending at the last site to streamline post-deployment cleanup.
